p: Awareness of heat warnings and risk perception may also play a role in disparities in heat-related vulnerability [ 14]. The extent to which individuals perceive risks associated with heat waves, which may be influenced by sociodemographic factors [ 15], can determine preventative actions they choose to take [ 16]. Moreover, risk perception of local natural hazards may inform perception of larger, more abstract topics, such as climate change risk [ 17]. A deeper understanding of how closely people link climate change to threats to their personal health and safety can improve climate change communication strategies and promote adaptive behaviors to protect health [ 18, 19].
